p.s: Attenborough starts his speech by simplifying the problem by referring to it as a single number (l. 3) with that people come back to the realization what they are actually aiming for.
To emphasize on how humankind is affected by the earth, he calls it our relationship with our the world (ll. 6-7), which makes it more personal.
The author alludes to the historic background of undefined ancient times, where the temperature was stabilized and expresses that part quite positive (e.g. 7-13).
In contrast to the following part where he enumerates how the planet is being destroyed and adds each to cause the personal pronoun our so that people feel addressed (e.g. l. 15, 16).
In addition to that, the contrast highlights the drastic change of times.
One thing that is striking is that he uses sarcasm when he says wasted no time in taking advantage (l. 12) because the politicians waste a lot of time when it is actually needed to act.
To express an urgency of this crisis, he uses an antithesis when he says until now (l. 14) and correct himself by saying already in trouble (l. 17).
His strategy for communication are the statements from different speakers that bring his argumentation on a personal level.
People are able to identify with those statements that address fear, and the feeling of being desperate (e.g. l. 21-23).
The statements are all negative in contrast to the following statements from different speakers that are motivated and optimistic (e.g. l. 42-46).
This is supposed to show the development of changing the mindset and way of thinking towards the issue.
It is also supposed to reflect how the audienceaudience's opinion should change.

To make it more personal, he mentions future generations and also underlines the fact that young people alive will have be affected by the crisis (e.g. l. 27) and illustrates the development by saying turn[ing] this tragedy into a triumph (l. 28).
Attenborough tries to convince the assembled by pushing their ego and stating that we [...] the greatest problem solvers (l. 29).
He underlines the urgenceurgance of acting with an anaphora We are (l. 28), We now..., we know, we must (ll. 29-34).
Can also be seen as a climax when he says we know, we must, we will (l. 29-34).

Instead of blaming one country for not progressing enough or praising a nation for the progress, he states that the countries are on a journey (l. 38) together and depend on each other in regards of the global warming.
To illustrate the pressure everyone is supposed to feel, he uses personification of the earth looking to everybody (e.g. l. 53).
To evoke pressure again, he uses the antithesis in my lifetime..., in yours... (ll. 51, 52) and distances himself from them.
At the end he frames his speech by changing the order of the people he addressed at the beginning of his speech.
In conclusion, one conceive that David Attenborough tries to strategically persuade the audience by presenting contrast and relying on inclusive language.
And lastly argument thing on a personal level.
